docs.lead_paragraph: A New Jersey judge today upheld the state's six-month-old law requiring a doctor to tell a parent before performing an abortion on an unmarried girl under 18. The ruling, however, did not clear the way for the law to become effective immediately. In September, New Jersey's Supreme Court, its highest tribunal, temporarily blocked enforcement of the law and created a procedure for a speedy lower-court ruling on its constitutionality, which came today. The Supreme Court also said, however, that it would take direct appeals of the lower court's decision and make a final ruling on the law, blocking enforcement of it until then.

headline.main: Abortion Law On Disclosure Is Upheld

docs.abstract: Abortion Law On Disclosure Is Upheld**New Jersey Superior Court Judge Marguerite T Simon upholds six-month-old law requiring doctor to tell parent before performing abortion on unmarried girl under 18; state Supreme Court will likely decide whether law is put into effect (M)
docs.snippet: A New Jersey judge today upheld the state's six-month-old law requiring a doctor to tell a parent before performing an abortion on an unmarried girl under 18.    The ruling, however, did not clear the way for the law to become effective immediately....

docs.lead_paragraph: A LAW that took effect in Connecticut on Oct. 1 requiring that newborns be tested for H.I.V. if their mothers refuse to be tested during pregnancy or delivery is being challenged by health providers, women's groups and civil libertarians. Opponents charged that the law is an invasion of privacy and will cause women to flee prenatal care. Supporters said it will help identify babies, and mothers, who test positive for H.I.V., enabling both to receive care.

headline.main: Groups Challenge New H.I.V. Testing Law

docs.abstract: Law that took effect in Connecticut on Oct 1 requiring that newborns be tested for HIV if their mothers refuse to be tested during pregnancy or delivery is being challenged by health providers, women's groups and civil libertarians; opponents charge that law is an invasion of privacy and will cause women to flee prenatal care; supporters say it will help identify babies, and mothers, who test positive for HIV, enabling both to receive care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory has agreed to pay $2.2 million in a settlement with thousands of employees who said their blood was illegally tested for sexual diseases, genetic conditions and pregnancy. The testing, now discontinued, was part of physical examinations given to newly hired clerical workers, starting about 30 years ago. Seven present and past employees said in a lawsuit that they were not told of the blood tests at the time and first learned about them years later.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Lab to Pay $2.2 Million To Settle Blood Test Case

docs.lead_paragraph: At this late date in the century -- the century defined by the American success story -- the two men considered most likely to succeed to the presidency are both running away from their pasts. One, brought up in a ritzy hotel by a Washington political family, has reinvented himself as a down-home Tennessean; the other, a political prince educated at Andover, Yale and Harvard, is now a man of the people in cowboy boots. The man whose job they covet, of course, is the former Bill Blythe, son of a traveling salesman and product of the disreputable gambling town of Hot Springs, Ark., who, via Georgetown, Oxford and Yale, long ago remade himself (for a while anyway) into the Man From Hope. In the parallel private realm of America -- that of business -- the folk hero du jour is Jim Clark, Silicon Valley entrepreneur extraordinaire, who, in the words of his chronicler Michael Lewis, has ''no past, only a future.'' A dirt-poor kid from Plainview, Tex., who was expelled from high school, Clark acquired new wives, friends and colleagues as he reinvented himself (on his way to retooling cyberspace) at the threshold of middle age.
docs.abstract: american pseudo** Frank Rich article on motion picture The Talented Mr Ripley as Hollywood's most chilling and up-to-date portrait of American national character; says Ripley asks us to identify with dark character who believes in democratic ethos that says anyone can jettison past and, with pluck and luck, be whoever he or she wants to be; says this ethos is shared by political candidates, entrepreneurs and criminals alike at time in which technological change not only encourages us to reinvent ourselves to find success or happiness, but increases the tools with which we can do so; notes that book on which movie was based is creation of Patricia Highsmith, who in 1991 revealed her own multiple identities; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: By the starchy standards of palace life, theirs has been anything but a conventional fairy tale. But with an abundance of patience, and some high-powered medical help, it seems that their dream has finally come true. After more than six years of a marriage filled with nervous speculation over whether Crown Prince Naruhito and his wife, Princess Masako, were able furnish a successor to the Chrysanthemum Throne, the Japanese people awoke to a flood of news reports today that the couple would appear to be bearers of good news.

headline.main: Tokyo Journal; Japanese Expectant, and Hope the Princess Is, Too

docs.abstract: Reports that Princess Masako is pregnant creates excitement in Japan; photo with Crown Prince Naruhito (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Dignity for the Tiniest Victims: Paramedics Arrange Funerals for Abandoned Infants'' (news article, Dec. 7): Perhaps with education, information and access to reproductive health care, these infants would have never been conceived. The parents should have had easy access to contraceptives and been educated about how to prevent a pregnancy.
docs.abstract: Letter by Michelle Interlicchio of Planned Parenthood on funerals for abandoned infants; says that every child deserves to be wanted and loved, and points out that reproductive health care can prevent conception of children who are not wanted (S)
